awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Post-transcriptional regulation of mRNA stability in Mycobacterium smegmatis
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand how bacteria adapt to stressful conditions, such as lack of nutrients or oxygen.  Bacteria are known to be able to modify their physiology in order to survive in under adverse conditions, but exactly how this occurs is not well-understood.  This work will explore how bacteria activate certain genes and stop using others in order to conserve energy in response to stress. Because bacteria affect human lives in many ways--by shaping our environment, influencing our health, and serving as important tools for research and industry--the results of this study should have far-reaching scientific impacts. In addition, this project will provide valuable training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, who will participate directly in the research in both laboratory and course-based settings. Educational impact will be broadened by developing tools and techniques as a platform for involving local high school students and their teachers in hands-on research in the lab and in computational analyses of research results. An educational module for teaching gene regulation will be developed and disseminated to high schools that serve underprivileged communities.  

Regulation of transcript abundance is critical to bacterial stress response, and can occur at the point of transcription or at the point of degradation. The contribution of post-transcriptional regulation of mRNA stability and function is poorly understood, particularly in mycobacteria, which differ from more commonly studied bacteria with respect to RNA metabolism. Using Mycobacterium smegmatis as a model organism, the objectives of this project are to (i) determine the impact of post-transcriptional regulation on transcript abundance and function in response to stress; (ii) identify mechanisms that globally stabilize mRNA during stress-induced growth inhibition; and (iii) define the roles and regulation of some of the central components of the mycobacterial mRNA degradation machinery. The approach will combine transcriptomics, genetics, biochemistry, and modeling to measure mRNA cleavage and degradation and test hypotheses about the regulation and phenotypic consequences of these processes. This work will generate foundational knowledge about the determinants of mRNA stability in mycobacteria and the contributions of post-transcriptional regulation to stress response. In the longer term, integration of information on transcriptional and post-transcriptional mechanisms is expected to lead to a comprehensive understanding of the stress tolerance mechanisms that render mycobacteria so successful in diverse environments.

por.por_cntn:
In “CAREER: Post-transcriptional regulation of mRNA stability in Mycobacterium smegmatis”, we completed a number of studies related to the fundamental biology of mycobacterial RNA processing as well as supported the training of people at a wide range of career stages. Overall, this work has provided foundational knowledge important for understanding the mycobacteria, a group that includes important human pathogens, as well as other groups of bacteria with important roles in the environment and human health.

One major focus area of this project was the determinants of mRNA degradation rates mycobacteria. We reported that energy stress leads to reduced mRNA degradation, while stressors that halt growth without causing energy stress do not, indicating that mRNA degradation rates are tied to metabolic state rather than growth. We reported that 5’ UTRs impact mRNA degradation rates in transcript-specific ways. In work yet to be published, we found that mRNA degradation rates are specified by the non-linear interactions of multiple transcript properties and that these properties impact degradation rates differentially in rapid growth and energy starvation.

Another major focus area was defining the roles of various mRNA degradation proteins in order to create a knowledge foundation for understanding how their activities are regulated. We defined the role of RNase E transcriptome-wide, identifying its targets and cleavage specificity in mycobacteria, which differs from that in better-studied model organisms. We likewise defined the role of mycobacterial RNase J. In work yet to be published we have made progress in defining the roles of other RNases, RNA helicases, and RNA binding proteins.

This work also produced large-scale datasets of use to the field, including transcriptome-wide maps of transcription start sites and RNA cleavage sites as well as transcriptome-wide measurements of mRNA half-lives in M. smegmatis. These were accompanied by development of methods for the production and analysis of these types of datasets.

This award financially supported 11 REU students, two additional undergraduates, a post-baccalaureate student, seven PhD students, a postdoctoral fellow, and a high school teacher. An additional five high school students, 11 undergraduates, four PhD students, and one high school teacher worked on the project while funded from other sources. Each of these trainees received research experience and mentorship appropriate for their career types and stages. This award has also facilitated development of improved undergraduate laboratory courses and a variety of outreach activities to local K12 schools and students. Together, the training, education, and outreach activities performed under this award have contributed to the strengthening and diversification of the nation’s scientific workforce.
